Holding secure elections is a civilizational IQ test

> 14 states don't require any ID at all to vote

> it's impossible to say that "cheating is rare" if you don't measure the thing at all 

> requiring proof of citizenship is incredibly popular among all Americans

> yet, the SAVE act *still* hasn't passed

What are we even doing?!

If we don't do this, we're not going to have the chance. It's that simple.

# Good News: Scientists discover a way to regrow cartilage, stop arthritis

Mister Retrops

Jan 23, 2026

The $65 billion per year global arthritis industry is in for quite a scare as scientists at Stanford just [announced](https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2026/01/260120000333.htm) they figured out how to regrow healthy, functioning cartilage and maybe end arthritis forever.

The treatment involved injecting a protein related to aging and resulted in brand-new shock-absorbing cartilage growing back between the joints.

It also stopped arthritis from developing after ACL tears.

From *Science Daily* :

> The protein at the center of the study is called 15-PGDH. Researchers refer to it as a gerozyme because its levels increase as the body ages.

If the protein is blocked, chondrocytes change how their genes behave, shifting into a more youthful state.

items.message:
- The post shares a January 20, 2026, Stanford study in *Nature Medicine* showing that inhibiting the protein 15-PGDH promotes cartilage regrowth in mice and human lab tissue, potentially halting arthritis progression without stem cells.
- Researchers, led by Helen Blau, found the treatment restores youthful chondrocyte function, increases prostaglandin E2, and has prior success in regenerating muscle and other tissues; phase 1 human trials for a related inhibitor confirmed safety.
- While promising for aging and injury-related arthritisâ€”affecting over 32 million U.S. adults per CDC dataâ€”experts note limitations as it's preclinical in humans, with oral pill development and cartilage-specific trials planned next.

result.text:
ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ WHEN JUDGES FORGET THEY'RE REFEREES, NOT PLAYERS

The Supreme Court confirmation process has become political theater because we've turned judges into politicians in robes. 

When every major decision splits 5-4 along predictable ideological lines, we're not seeing legal interpretation; we're seeing policy preferences dressed up as jurisprudence.

This is a system problem. 

The real damage isn't any single ruling but the erosion of public trust. 

When citizens can predict how judges will rule based on who appointed them, the law becomes just politics by other means. 

Judges are supposed to be referees calling balls and strikes, not players trying to win the game themselves. 

Here's what's been lost: the idea that legal questions have legal answers, not just political ones. 

When judges start from their desired outcome and work backward to find justification, they're not interpreting law; they're making it.
